prompt: Facts: The petitioner, Sushil Kumar Sharma, filed a Writ Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.; The petition challenged the constitutional validity of Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), 1860.; The primary contention was that Section 498A was being widely misused by disgruntled wives and their families to harass husbands and their relatives.; It was argued that the provision led to automatic arrests, violated fundamental rights, and was used as a tool for extortion and 'legal terrorism'.; The petitioner argued that the vague language of Section 498A, particularly the definition of 'cruelty', allowed for arbitrary application.; The petitioner contended that the section violated Articles 14 (Equality before law), 19 (Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc.), and 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty) of the Constitution.; The Union of India, as the primary respondent, defended the constitutionality of the section, highlighting its objective to protect women from marital cruelty and dowry-related harassment.; The Supreme Court considered the legislative intent, the scope of the provision, arguments regarding its misuse, and its constitutional validity. | IPC: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)
